questions.text: No cartilage is found between tragus and the crux of helix ; this area is called :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Incisura terminalis. The incisura terminalis (intertragic notch) is the region between the tragus and the crus of the helix that lacks cartilage. This anatomical feature creates a small notch-like depression in the auricle (external ear). Since there is no cartilage in this area, it is more flexible compared to other parts of the auricle that are supported by cartilage. This notch serves as a distinguishing landmark in the anatomy of the external ear. Incorrect Options: A. Tragus The tragus is a small cartilaginous projection in front of the external auditory canal. It plays a role in directing sound waves into the ear but is not the area between the tragus and the crux of the helix. B. Antitragus The antitragus is a small tubercle located opposite the tragus, separated by the intertragic notch. It is cartilaginous and does not correspond to the area in question. C. Cymba conchae The cymba conchae is the upper, deeper part of the concha (the hollow leading to the external auditory canal). It is not located between the tragus and the crux of the helix.

choices.text: 10 mm tall,9 mm wide and 0.1 mm thick
1 mm tall,9 mm wide and 0.1 mm thick
10 mm tall,9 mm wide and 1 mm thick
1 mm tall,9 mm wide and 1 mm thick

questions.text: Dimension of tympanic membrane is :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 10 mm tall, 9 mm wide, and 0.1 mm thick. The tympanic membrane (eardrum) is a thin, oval-shaped structure that separates the external auditory canal from the middle ear. It plays a crucial role in sound conduction by vibrating in response to sound waves. The typical dimensions of the tympanic membrane are: Height (superior-inferior): ~10 mm Width (anterior-posterior): ~9 mm Thickness: ~0.1 mm (very thin, allowing for efficient sound transmission) These dimensions ensure that the eardrum is thin enough to be highly responsive to sound waves while being strong enough to maintain its function. Incorrect Options: (B) 1 mm tall, 9 mm wide, and 0.1 mm thick The tympanic membrane is much larger than 1 mm in height. A height of 10 mm is the correct measurement. (C) 10 mm tall, 9 mm wide, and 1 mm thick While the height (10 mm) and width (9 mm) are correct, the tympanic membrane is not 1 mm thick. It is extremely thin, around 0.1 mm, which allows it to vibrate efficiently. (D) 1 mm tall, 9 mm wide, and 1 mm thick Both the height (1 mm) and thickness (1 mm) are incorrect. The actual membrane is 10 mm tall and only 0.1 mm thick.

questions.text: The following structure represents all the three components of the embryonic disc:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Tympanic membrane. The tympanic membrane (eardrum) is unique because it develops from all three germ layers of the embryonic disc: Ectoderm – Forms the outer epithelial layer (derived from the first pharyngeal cleft). Mesoderm – Forms the fibrous connective tissue layer in the middle, which provides structural support. Endoderm – Forms the inner mucosal layer (derived from the first pharyngeal pouch). Since the tympanic membrane consists of all three embryonic layers, it represents the entire trilaminar embryonic disc. Incorrect Options: (B) Retina The retina is derived entirely from the neuroectoderm (an extension of the diencephalon). It does not contain all three germ layers. (C) Meninges The meninges (dura mater, arachnoid mater, and pia mater) mainly originate from the mesoderm and neural crest cells (which are ectodermal in origin). However, they do not contain the endoderm layer. (D) None of the above Since the tympanic membrane is derived from all three germ layers, this option is incorrect.

questions.text: Most of the medial surface of pinnae is supplied by :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) A & B (Greater auricular nerve and Lesser occipital nerve). The medial surface of the pinna (auricle) is primarily supplied by: Greater auricular nerve (C2, C3) – A branch of the cervical plexus, which supplies most of the medial surface and the lower part of the lateral surface of the auricle. Lesser occipital nerve (C2) – Another branch of the cervical plexus, which supplies the upper part of the medial surface of the auricle. Since both these nerves provide the majority of the sensory innervation to the medial surface of the pinna, the correct answer is option D (A & B). Incorrect Options: (A) Greater auricular nerve While the greater auricular nerve does supply most of the medial pinna, it is not the only contributor. The lesser occipital nerve also plays a role, so this option alone is incomplete. (B) Lesser occipital nerve The lesser occipital nerve supplies the upper part of the medial surface but does not supply the lower part, which is covered by the greater auricular nerve. (C) Auriculotemporal nerve The auriculotemporal nerve (branch of the mandibular nerve, CN V3) primarily supplies the anterior and superior parts of the lateral surface of the auricle, not the medial surface.

questions.text: Identify the congenital abnormality:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Bat ear. Bat ear (Prominent ear or Otoplastasis) is a congenital ear deformity where the ear protrudes abnormally from the head. It can be unilateral or bilateral and results from cartilage malformation during early fetal development. Key features include: Large concha Poorly developed antihelix and scapha Excessive auriculocephalic angle (ear sticks out more than normal) This condition is purely cosmetic and does not affect hearing. It can be corrected surgically via otoplasty. Incorrect Options: (B) Mozart ear Mozart ear is characterized by a bulging auricle, convex cavum concha, and a narrow external auditory canal. It is named after the composer Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart, who was believed to have this deformity. It does not involve a prominent ear. (C) Wildermuth ear Wildermuth’s ear is a congenital anomaly where the antihelix is enlarged, and the helix bends downward, giving the ear an unusual shape. This is different from bat ear, which mainly involves an increased auriculocephalic angle. (D) Mondini dysplasia Mondini dysplasia is a malformation of the inner ear that affects the cochlea, leading to sensorineural hearing loss. It has nothing to do with external ear shape.

questions.text: Instrumentation of the external canal can cause nausea or coughing through stimulation of the:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) 10th cranial nerve (Vagus nerve). The external auditory canal is innervated by multiple cranial nerves, but the auricular branch of the vagus nerve (Arnold’s nerve) is particularly significant because it has autonomic and sensory functions. Stimulation of Arnold’s nerve (e.g., during ear canal instrumentation, cleaning, or foreign body removal) can activate the cough reflex (Arnold’s reflex) and, in some cases, cause nausea due to vagal stimulation. This happens because the vagus nerve also innervates the larynx, pharynx, and gastrointestinal tract, which are involved in reflexive responses like coughing and nausea. Incorrect Options: (A) 5th cranial nerve (Trigeminal nerve) The trigeminal nerve (CN V) provides sensory innervation to parts of the external ear (via the auriculotemporal nerve, a branch of V3), but it does not trigger coughing or nausea. (B) 7th cranial nerve (Facial nerve) The facial nerve (CN VII) contributes to sensation in the concha but does not cause a vagal reflex like coughing or nausea. (C) 9th cranial nerve (Glossopharyngeal nerve) The glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) primarily innervates the oropharynx and posterior tongue and is responsible for the gag reflex, not the cough reflex.

questions.text: External ear canal is fully formed by: -
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The external ear canal (external auditory meatus) develops from the first pharyngeal cleft. The development occurs in stages: By 6th–8th week: The meatal plug (solid epithelial proliferation) forms at the bottom of the external auditory canal. By 20th week: The meatal plug begins to recanalize, forming the early lumen of the canal. By 28th week: The external auditory canal is fully formed and patent. Thus, the external auditory canal is completely developed by the 28th week of gestation, making option (D) the correct answer. Incorrect Options: (A) 6th week At this stage, only the meatal plug has formed, and the canal is not yet developed. (B) 8th week The external canal remains blocked by the meatal plug and has not yet started recanalization. (C) 20th week The canal begins to open, but full formation and patency occur by 28 weeks.

questions.text: Direction of water jet while doing syringing of ear should be :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Poster superior. When performing ear syringing, directing the water jet in a poster superior direction aligns with the natural curvature of the external auditory canal. This approach helps ensure that the water flows smoothly along the canal, effectively dislodging cerumen while avoiding direct impact on the tympanic membrane. The poster superior direction minimizes the risk of injury by keeping the force of the water away from the delicate anterior structures of the ear. (A) Anterior Directing the water jet anteriorly may result in water striking the tympanic membrane or the anterior canal wall directly, increasing the risk of injury or discomfort. (C) Anterosuperior While anterosuperior is somewhat similar to the correct direction, it does not accurately follow the natural curvature of the ear canal. This misalignment may lead to less effective cleaning and a higher risk of impacting sensitive areas. (D) Posteroinferior A posteroinferior direction does not conform to the typical anatomical orientation of the ear canal. This can lead to inefficient removal of cerumen and might also risk directing water towards structures that should be protected.

questions.text: A new born presents with bilateral microtia and external auditory canal atresia. Corrective surgery is usually performed is :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 5-7 years of age. Corrective surgery for bilateral microtia with external auditory canal atresia is typically performed around 5-7 years of age because by this time, the child's ear structures have grown sufficiently, allowing for more successful reconstructive outcomes. Additionally, waiting until this age permits better cooperation from the child during postoperative care and rehabilitation. The timing also ensures that hearing aids and other supportive measures have been optimally utilized before considering surgical reconstruction. Incorrect Options: (A) < 1 year of age Infants under one year do not have adequately developed ear structures, and performing surgery this early poses higher risks with lower success rates. (C) Puberty Although puberty indicates further growth, delaying the surgery until puberty might hinder early auditory and social development, and the surgical outcomes may not be optimal if the ear structures are already fully matured. (D) Adulthood Postponing surgery until adulthood delays intervention unnecessarily, potentially affecting speech, hearing, and social integration during formative years.

questions.text: After rupture of tympanic membrane the hearing loss is :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Average hearing loss seen in different lesions of conductive apparatus: 1. Complete obstruction of ear canal : 30dB 2.Perforation of tympanic membrane : 10 - 40dB ( It varies and is directly proportional to the size of perforation ) 3. Ossicular interruption with intact drum : 54dB 4. Ossicular interruption with perforation : 38dB 5. Closure of oval window : 60dB Option (A) is therefore the correct option.

questions.text: Last component of the pinna to develop is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Lobule. The lobule, which is the soft, non-cartilaginous lower part of the external ear, is the last component of the pinna to develop. Unlike the other parts of the pinna, the lobule is composed mainly of adipose and connective tissue, and its development occurs later compared to the cartilaginous structures. This delayed formation accounts for its unique consistency and position in the ear anatomy. Incorrect Options: (A) Tragus The tragus develops from the first pharyngeal arch and forms relatively early in the embryological development of the ear. (C) Helix The helix, which is the curved outer rim of the ear, is one of the primary cartilaginous structures and develops early as part of the initial formation of the pinna. (D) Antihelix Similar to the helix and tragus, the antihelix forms from the embryonic hillocks and is part of the cartilaginous framework that develops before the lobule.

choices.text: Keratin plugs should be initially removed with acetic acid

questions.text: Select the most inappropriate statement regarding “Keratosis Obturans”
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The most inappropriate statement regarding Keratosis Obturans is (D) Associated with frequent ear discharge. Keratosis Obturans is characterized by an abnormal accumulation of keratin debris within the external auditory canal. This buildup is typically non-infectious and is more associated with symptoms such as severe ear pain (otalgia), a sensation of fullness, and conductive hearing loss rather than with recurrent or frequent ear discharge. Ear discharge is more characteristic of conditions like chronic otitis externa or cholesteatoma, not keratosis obturans. Therefore, stating that it is associated with frequent ear discharge is inaccurate. Incorrect Options: Option (A) Is a growth abnormality This statement is appropriate. Although Keratosis Obturans is not a neoplastic growth, it does represent an abnormal accumulation (or "growth") of keratin within the ear canal, leading to obstruction and subsequent symptoms. Option (B) Keratin plugs should be initially removed with acetic acid This is correct. In the management of Keratosis Obturans, the keratin plugs are often softened and facilitated for removal by using solutions such as acetic acid, which helps in loosening the plug for safer extraction. Option (C) Usually bilateral This statement is also accurate. Keratosis Obturans is typically a bilateral condition, distinguishing it from other ear canal pathologies that might present unilaterally.

questions.text: Wet Newspaper’ like appearance in external auditory canal is a feature of
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Otomycosis. In otomycosis, a fungal infection of the external auditory canal, the accumulation of fungal debris, keratin, and inflammatory exudates often produces a distinctive "wet newspaper" appearance. This description refers to the grayish, flaky, and sometimes moist debris that coats the canal, mimicking the texture and look of a wet newspaper. Incorrect Options: (A) Localised otitis externa Localized otitis externa is typically a bacterial infection that causes localized inflammation and discharge, but it does not usually produce the characteristic "wet newspaper" debris seen in fungal infections. (C) Exostosis Exostosis refers to bony growths within the ear canal, often seen in individuals exposed to cold water (commonly known as "surfer's ear"). It is a structural abnormality and does not cause a flaky, debris-like appearance. (D) Diffuse otitis externa Diffuse otitis externa involves widespread inflammation of the ear canal, generally due to bacterial infection, leading to swelling, pain, and sometimes watery discharge, but not the specific "wet newspaper" appearance.

choices.text: Abnormal collection of cerumen in the outer part of external auditory canal
Abnormal collection of cerumen in the deeper part of external auditory canal
Abnormal epithelial migration of skin of external auditory canal
Chronic foul smelling ear discharge present in external auditory canal

questions.text: Keratosis obturans is caused due to
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Abnormal epithelial migration of skin of external auditory canal. Keratosis obturans is characterized by an abnormal buildup of keratin debris in the external auditory canal. This condition occurs due to a disruption in the normal process of epithelial migration, which is responsible for the regular, outward shedding of keratin. When this migration is impaired or altered, excessive keratin accumulates, leading to a plug-like formation in the deeper part of the canal. This buildup can result in symptoms such as ear pain, hearing loss, and sometimes a sensation of fullness. Incorrect Options: (A) Abnormal collection of cerumen in the outer part of external auditory canal This option describes cerumen impaction, which involves earwax accumulation rather than keratin debris. Cerumen impaction is a different condition and does not account for the pathology seen in keratosis obturans. (B) Abnormal collection of cerumen in the deeper part of external auditory canal Similar to option (A), this describes an issue with earwax rather than a problem with epithelial migration and keratin accumulation. Keratosis obturans specifically involves keratin, not cerumen. (D) Chronic foul smelling ear discharge present in external auditory canal Foul smelling discharge is typically associated with chronic infections or cholesteatoma, not keratosis obturans. This option does not address the underlying cause, which is the abnormal epithelial migration leading to keratin accumulation.

questions.text: Constriction of the helix and scapha lead to:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Cup Ear Deformity. In this deformity, constriction or abnormal folding of the helix and scapha leads to a distinctive cup-like or "constricted" appearance of the pinna. The deformation results in a reduced, compressed shape of the ear, often making it appear smaller and less defined compared to a normally developed ear. Explanation of Incorrect Options (A) Protruding Ear Protruding ear, or "bat ear," is characterized by an increased auriculocephalic angle where the ear projects away from the head. It is not typically caused by constriction of the helix and scapha. (B) Cryptotia Cryptotia occurs when the upper portion of the ear is hidden beneath the scalp or temporal skin, rather than being exposed. It involves a different mechanism of ear malposition, not the constriction of the helix and scapha. (D) Colobomata Colobomata refer to a defect or a notch in the ear, most often involving the helix. This is a localized defect rather than the global constriction seen in cup ear deformity.

questions.text: True unilateral neoplastic benign outgrowth in the external auditory canal:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Osteoma. Osteomas are true neoplastic benign bony outgrowths that arise from the osseous structures of the external auditory canal (EAC). They are typically solitary, unilateral, and slow-growing, and they often present as a pedunculated mass. Their neoplastic nature differentiates them from other conditions that involve non-neoplastic accumulations or multiple bony growths. Incorrect Options: (A) Papilloma Papillomas are benign epithelial neoplasms that often occur in the skin or mucosal surfaces, including the EAC, but they are not bony growths. Additionally, they are usually associated with viral infections and do not represent a true neoplastic bony outgrowth. (C) Keratosis Obturans Keratosis Obturans is characterized by the accumulation of keratin debris in the deeper parts of the EAC due to abnormal epithelial migration. It is not a neoplastic process, but rather a non-neoplastic blockage by keratin plugs. (D) Exostoses Exostoses are bony outgrowths as well, but they are typically multiple and bilateral, and are usually associated with chronic exposure to cold water (commonly known as "surfer's ear"). They are reactive rather than true neoplastic lesions.

questions.text: External auditory canal cholesteatoma caused by blockage of the EAC permitting accumulation of epithelial debris is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Keratosis Obturans. Keratosis Obturans is a condition where there is a blockage of the external auditory canal (EAC) that leads to the accumulation of epithelial debris, forming a plug. This accumulation mimics a cholesteatoma in the EAC but is due to the abnormal migration or shedding of the epithelial lining rather than an invasive growth. The build-up of keratin results in a mass that can obstruct the canal and lead to conductive hearing loss along with other symptoms such as pain. Incorrect Options: Option (A) Papilloma Papilloma is a benign epithelial tumor often associated with viral infections. It presents as a wart-like lesion rather than an accumulation of keratin debris. Option (B) Osteoma Osteoma is a benign bony outgrowth within the EAC. It is not caused by epithelial debris accumulation but by a true neoplastic process of the bony tissue. Option (D) Exostoses Exostoses are bony growths usually found in multiple numbers and are often bilateral. They are related to chronic exposure to cold water ("surfer’s ear") and do not involve the accumulation of epithelial debris.

questions.text: Appropriate treatment for an acute stable hematoma of the pinna of the ear includes which of the following measures?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The correct treatment for an acute stable hematoma of the pinna is (D) Incision, drainage, and pressure bandage. In an auricular hematoma, blood collects between the perichondrium and the cartilage, risking cartilage necrosis and potential deformity (cauliflower ear) if not promptly managed. Incision and drainage allow for complete evacuation of the hematoma, and applying a pressure bandage reapposes the perichondrium to the cartilage, promoting revascularization and preventing re-accumulation of blood. Incorrect Options: (A) Ice packs and prophylactic antibiotics While ice packs and antibiotics may serve as supportive measures to reduce swelling and prevent infection, they are insufficient on their own for evacuating the hematoma, which is crucial to prevent cartilage damage. (B) Excision of the hematoma Excision is not the appropriate management for an acute hematoma. Removing tissue can cause unnecessary trauma and does not address the underlying need to drain the accumulated blood and reapply the perichondrium to the cartilage. (C) Needle aspiration Needle aspiration may not effectively remove all the clotted blood from the space, and it has a higher risk of recurrence. It is generally not preferred because it may not fully relieve the pressure on the cartilage, risking further complications.

questions.text: Multiple or bilateral smooth sessile protrusions of the medial bony canal is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Exostoses. Exostoses are multiple, bilateral, smooth, sessile bony protrusions found typically in the medial portion of the bony external auditory canal. They often develop as a reactive process in response to chronic exposure to cold water, earning them the nickname "surfer's ear." Their appearance as smooth, broad-based growths distinguishes them from other lesions of the ear canal. Incorrect Options: (A) Papilloma Papillomas are benign epithelial tumors that usually present as wart-like or cauliflower-like growths. They are not bony in nature and do not appear as smooth, sessile protrusions in the bony canal. (B) Osteoma Osteomas are benign bony tumors but are typically solitary, unilateral, and pedunculated. They usually occur in the lateral part of the external auditory canal rather than being multiple or bilateral. (C) Keratosis Obliterans Keratosis Obliterans (also known as Keratosis Obturans) involves the accumulation of keratin debris leading to canal obstruction, not bony protrusions. It is an epithelial disorder, not a bony condition.

questions.text: Most common organism associated with “Osteomyelitis of the Skull Base’:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Pseudomonas. Skull base osteomyelitis, often referred to in the context of malignant otitis externa, is most commonly caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa. This pathogen is known for its aggressive nature, particularly in elderly diabetic or immunocompromised patients, where it can invade the external auditory canal and spread to the skull base, leading to osteomyelitis. Incorrect Options: (A) Streptococcus Although Streptococcus species can cause various infections, they are not the typical organisms responsible for skull base osteomyelitis. (B) Staphylococcus Staphylococcus aureus is a common cause of osteomyelitis in other parts of the body, but in cases of skull base osteomyelitis associated with malignant otitis externa, Pseudomonas aeruginosa is the predominant pathogen. (C) H.influenzae Haemophilus influenzae is more commonly associated with respiratory infections and does not play a significant role in the pathogenesis of skull base osteomyelitis.

questions.text: Clinical evidence of malignant otitis externa with infection of soft tissues beyond the external auditory canal but negative Tc-99 Bone scan is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Stage 1. In malignant otitis externa, Stage 1 is defined by clinical evidence of infection that extends into the soft tissues beyond the external auditory canal, yet without any radiological evidence of bony involvement. A negative Tc-99 bone scan confirms that there is no osteomyelitis, which distinguishes Stage 1 from higher stages where bone involvement is evident. Incorrect Options: Stage 2 In Stage 2, the infection has progressed to involve the bone, which is typically demonstrated by a positive Tc-99 bone scan. Since the bone scan is negative in this scenario, it does not meet the criteria for Stage 2. Stage 3 Stage 3 is associated with more extensive disease, including complications such as cranial nerve involvement or further extension into adjacent structures. This advanced stage is not indicated by a negative bone scan and the clinical scenario provided. Stage 4 Stage 4 involves intracranial extension and severe complications, representing the most advanced form of the disease. This stage would be characterized by significant findings on imaging studies, which are not present in this case.

choices.text: Technetium scan is more useful in the prognostic evaluation of this entity
ESR can be used to monitor the progression of disease
Facial nerve is the most commonly involved nerve

questions.text: All are true about malignant otitis externa except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Technetium scan is more useful in the prognostic evaluation of this entity. This statement is inappropriate because, while Technetium-99m bone scans are highly sensitive for detecting osteomyelitis at the skull base, they are not reliable for prognostic evaluation. Once positive, Technetium scans may remain so for many months despite clinical improvement. For monitoring treatment response and disease progression, other parameters—such as ESR (erythrocyte sedimentation rate), CRP, and even Gallium scans—are considered more useful. Option (C) ESR can be used to monitor the progression of disease – This is a correct statement. ESR is a useful marker for inflammation and can help clinicians monitor the progression or resolution of skull base osteomyelitis during treatment. Option (D) Facial nerve is the most commonly involved nerve – Although various cranial nerves may be affected in skull base osteomyelitis, the involvement of the facial nerve is well documented. While not as consistently involved as suggested by some reports, this statement is generally acceptable compared to the inaccuracy of option (B).

questions.text: A 25 year old young Swimmer came with the complaints of itching and pain in right ear since 2 days. On examination the patient cried as the surgeon pulled the ear Pinna. He also noticed that the ear canal was narrowed, edematous and the skin is red. The disease the swimmer is suffering from?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Acute Diffuse External Otitis. This condition, often referred to as "swimmer's ear," is an acute bacterial infection of the external auditory canal. It typically presents with pain, itching, and tenderness of the ear canal. The infection causes inflammation and edema, which narrows the canal and results in redness of the skin. The extreme pain elicited when the ear pinna is pulled is also a classic sign of this condition. Incorrect Options: (A) Furuncle A furuncle is a localized infection of a hair follicle, usually presenting as a solitary, painful, erythematous nodule. It does not typically cause diffuse narrowing or widespread edema of the external auditory canal. (C) Malignant Otitis Externa Malignant otitis externa is a severe, invasive infection that primarily affects elderly or immunocompromised individuals, particularly diabetics. It is far less common in a young, healthy 25-year-old swimmer. (D) Otomycosis Otomycosis is a fungal infection of the external auditory canal, which often presents with itching and sometimes mild discomfort. However, it is usually associated with a buildup of fungal debris rather than the acute, painful, and edematous presentation seen in this case.
